Programming-for-AI-2024.title: Programming For AI
Programming-for-AI-2024.courseInstructor: Dr. P. N. Karthik
Programming-for-AI-2024.courseDescription: This course offers a comprehensive introduction to the fundamentals of programming in Python, tailored for students embarking on their journey into AI and ML. Throughout the course, students will gain hands-on experience by implementing essential AI/ML tasks from scratch. The curriculum provides an in-depth exploration of fundamental Python data types, functions, loops, conditional statements, tuples, lists, and dictionaries. Additionally, students will be exposed to the powerful libraries in Python such as Pandas, NumPy, SciPy, Matplotlib, and Seaborn, equipping them with the tools necessary for sophisticated data analysis and visualization. As part of the exercise sets, students will engage in practical data analysis using real-world datasets from neuroscience, and implement core AI/ML tasks, including the training of artificial neural networks (ANNs), backpropagation, $k$-means clustering, and $k$-nearest neighbor classification, all from scratch. The course is designed to facilitate students who intend to pursue projects in deep learning and/or reinforcement learning in their subsequent semesters.

Probability-2024.title: Probability And Stochastic Processes
Probability-2024.courseInstructor: Dr. P. N. Karthik
Probability-2024.courseDescription: This is a graduate-level course on probability, with emphasis on development of concepts from a measure-theoretic perspective. In the first half, the course will introduce the students to the modern theory of probability, as expounded by Kolmogorov. In the second half, the students will be introduced to the theory of discrete time Markov chains and Poisson processes. See below for a comprehensive list of topics that will be covered in the course.

courseContents.title: Course Contents
courseContents.description: Functions, cardinality, countability, sample space, events, algebra, $\sigma$-algebra, probability measure, properties of probability measures, continuity of probability, conditional probability and Bayes' Theorem, independence of events, random variables and measurability, functions of random variables, expectations as Lebesgue integrals, independence of random variables, computer simulation of random variables, moment generating function, characteristic function, Borel-Cantelli lemma, strong law of large numbers, weak law of large numbers, central limit theorem, sequences of random variables and their convergence, Gaussian random vectors, discrete event random processes, discrete time Markov chains, state space and transition probability matrix, Chapman-Kolmogorov equation, recurrence and transience, stationary distributions, ergodic theorem, Poisson processes, merging and splitting of Poisson processes.

list.title: Course logistics.

Functions, cardinality, countability, examples of countable sets, proof of countability of $\mathbb{Q}$, uncountable sets, examples of uncountable sets, proof of uncountability of $\{0,1\}^{\mathbb{N}}$ via Cantor's diagonalisation argument.

Motivation for an axiomatic theory of probability -- Bertrand's paradox, definition of sample space, definition of algebra, need for $\sigma$-algebra, definition of $\sigma$-algebra, events, measurable sets, measurable space, measure, measure space, finite measure, infinite measure, probability measure, probability space.

Properties of probability measures, the union bound, the $\liminf$ (all but finitely many) event, the $\limsup$ (infinitely many or infinitely often) event, continuity of probability measure, probability measures on discrete (countable) sample spaces, probability measures on uncountable probability measures, Borel $\sigma$-algebra, $\mathscr{B}([0,1])$, Caratheodory's extension theorem, Lebesgue measure on $\mathscr{B}([0,1])$, $\mathscr{B}(\mathbb{R})$ and Lebesgue measure on $\mathscr{B}(\mathbb{R})$, Cantor set -- construction, properties, and Lebesgue measure.

Conditional probability measure, law of total probability, Bayes' Theorem, independence of a collection of events, independence of a collection of $\sigma$-algebras, Borel-Cantelli lemma, random variables and measurability, probability law of a random variable, cumulative distribution function (CDF) and its properties.

Discrete random variables, probability mass function (PMF), CDF from PMF, examples of discrete random variables, continuous random variables, probability density function (PDF), examples of continuous random variables, multiple random variables, definition of a pair of random variables as a measurable function, joint probability law of two random variables, joint CDF of two random variables.

<span>Properties of joint CDF of two random variables, marginal CDFs from joint CDF, probability law and joint CDF of multiple random variables, jointly discrete random variables, joint PMF, marginal PMFs from joint PMF, conditional PMF, jointly continuous random variables, joint PDF, example where two random variables are individually continuous but not jointly continuous.

<span>Joint PDF of jointly continuous random variables, properties of joint PDF, conditional PDF, functions of random variables, definition of Borel-measurable functions, showing that maximum and minimum of random variables are random variables and deriving their corresponding CDFs, showing that the sum of two random variables is a random variable, convolution formula for the PMF/PDF of the sum of two random variables when the participating random variables are jointly discrete/continuous, showing that the sum of random number of random variables is a random variable.

<span>Deriving the CDF of random sum of random variables, Jacobian formula for single and multivariable transformations, primer on Riemann integration, expectation of a simple random variable, expectation of a non-negative random variable, expectation of an arbitrary random variable, preliminary properties of expectation.

<span>Expectations of simple random variables, primer on real analysis: supremum and infimum of a set of real numbers, supremum and infimum of a sequence of real numbers, limit supremum and limit infimum of a sequence of real numbers, limit of a sequence of real numbers, demonstrating that supremum, infimum, limit supremum, and limit infimum of a sequence of random variables is a extended real-valued random variable.

<span>Pointwise convergence of a sequence of random variables, construction of a monotone sequence of simple random variables that converge pointwise to a non-negative random variable, Monotone Convergence Theorem or MCT (a simpler version based on pointwise convergence) and expectations of non-negative random variables via MCT, expectations of discrete random variables via PMF, expectations on different spaces.

<span>Expectations on different spaces (continued), absolute continuity of measures, Radon--Nikodym theorem, expectations of continuous random variables, variance, covariance, uncorrelated random variables, independence and uncorrelatedness.

<span>Uncorrelatedness and independence (continued), correlation coefficient, Cauchy-Schwartz inequality, $\mathcal{L}^{p}$ vector spaces (for $1 \leq p < +\infty$), $\mathcal{L}^2$ vector space and inner products, interpretation of correlation coefficient as cosine of the angle for zero-mean random variables, conditional expectations -- introduction, computation of conditional expectation for jointly discrete and jointly continuous random variables.

<span>Conditional expectations (continued), law of iterated expectations, problems on conditional expectations, conditioning on an event, some miscellaneous problems on conditional expectations, geometric interpretation of conditional expectation as minimum mean-squared error (MMSE) estimator.
